Custom models can already use namespaces, any model in assets/<namespace>/models/ is a model under a different namespace.

Agreed on scoreboard objectives, and additionally, teams and tags (from /tag).

Edit: oh, you mean the CustomModelData NBT tag, right.

The only reason as to why I'd really want scoreboards to use resource-locations instead is because of the old scoreboard-id limit which allows you to define an id of only 16 characters which is pretty limited and can therefore easily lead to unwanted usage of same ids of different datapacks.

Also, take a look at bossbars which they've implemented in a fortunate way back in 1.13 by using resource-locations, which whould have been the perfect opportunity for them to make scoreboards do that aswell during the 1.13 snapshots.

Same goes for the current 1.15 "storage data" feature which also uses resource-locations.

Or they should at least change the limit to be more than 16.

A change to CustomModelData using namespaces wouldn't do much of a difference because of how you need to setup the item-model-file to get that tag to work. A resourcepack needs to "replace" such a file and if multiple packs replace the same file, only the highest prioritized pack will have that model overriden.

This would make more sense if we could append to data instead ot replacing it, just like a tag-file.
Namespaces could also enable auto-cleanup of unused scoreboard objectives when their corresponding datapack is removed.

This is something important to me also. Potentially incredibly useful, especially the modulus function for non-integer values

examples:

  • data operation storage minecraft:test foo[0].bar %= value 1
  • data operation entity @s Pos[0] *= score @s objectivename
  • data operation block ~ ~ ~ Items[{Slot:0b}].Count -= data entity @s Age

Yes this would be amazing, but we already have /scoreboard player operation, meaning if you used execute's storage sub command, with score, and /data get, you could make the same effect if you used /data modify to set it from something.
hmm... u need to explain more, i mean does this gamerule affect droppers? i mean this gamerule would only prevent player from droping items or it would prevent items from exist?

This is already possible with the current commands; we don't need a new gamerule.

It's as simple as putting this command into a repeating command block in a constantly loaded chunk, or putting it in a function tagged in #minecraft:tick

/execute as @e[type=item] run data merge entity @s {PickupDelay:0s}

This makes it impossible to drop any time because you will instantly pick it up again. You can optimize it so that it only affects items that have the Age 0 (i.e. the only items that could have been recently dropped).

/execute as @e[type=item,nbt={Age:0s}] run data merge entity @s {PickupDelay:0s}

You can further make it more specific so that it only affects items of a specific type (I used stone as an example):

/execute as @e[type=item,nbt={Age:0s,Item:{id:"minecraft:stone"}}] run data merge entity @s {PickupDelay:0s}

or items with some other NBT tag (I used "items enchanted with Sharpness V" as an example here):

/execute as @e[type=item,nbt={Age:0s,Item:{tag:{Enchantments:[{id:"minecraft:sharpness",lvl:5}]}}}] run data merge entity @s {PickupDelay:0s}

You can see a full list of all the different NBT tags that an item could have here:

https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Player.dat_format#Item_structure

Hope this helps!

Time could just be a mechanic, and the game could improve memorizing states and constantly be tracking things such as number and state of all blocks/objects in a world, block placement, world states, seasons, death time and location, and player/other inventories over the course of in game time. Exact date could be represented as a coordinate.

I wouldn't expect much, especially at first because of system requirements. I imagine it would be impossible to memorize exact player or mob movements, for example. Maybe it could be done to an extent though.

This would mostly be an opportunity to have the game automatically save more/introduce the ability to travel further forwards or backwards in time. You can already skip (aka time travel) to the next morning by sleeping in a bed at the beginning of night, so if commands were input via creative menus, or an exact date input into a time machine* (see time machine item post) the player(s) would get a chance to go to a previous, current, or future time and date, but at current coordinates. Since you can't turn off the autosave feature anymore, if you die and lose an item, it's gone. A good way to think about this is like a new coordinate; a new category of location. It'd enable one to farm crops/resources that aren't currently ready for harvest, revisit past destroyed structures, bring back deceased companions as long as they were named with a nametag, and undo undesired actions (going afk to have your house be blown up by a creeper.)

This! I recently spent 3 days building a gold farm in the Nether that relied on entity cramming only to find out that it doesn't even exist in Bedrock edition! This was in addition to various differences in pathing rules, aggro ranges, and piglins not picking up ingots through a corner...

I think the entity cramming should be enabled by default, so those of us who want achievements can still make use of it. Make it the same setting as Java Edition: 24, and have it be a gamerule so that those who dislike it can easily turn it off.
